exec: // we are authorised and the csrf-tokem is also valid. We need to set the x-csrf-token so the call is quicker.
// Performing a 'fetch' of the x-csrf-token makes the call longer and its unnecessary. Setting the x-csrf-token to a valid value
// will speed things up by a small fraction (which can be a lot of time if making thousands of calls!)
// we are not authorised, so our accesstoken or the csrf-token must be invalid. We shall get new ones of each!
// A 401 error might be because something is wrong with the call or even the SAP SAC SCIM API, so we need to start counting errors,
// so we don't end up in an endless loop.
if (!errors) { errors=0 };  // in case errors has not yet been set we need to set it to 0
console.log(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Fetching a new access token');
postman.setNextRequest("GET accesstoken"); // once a new accesstoken is successfully returned this call will be repeated thanks to the 'recovery' variable set in the pre-request
// No user so we can't update the user. Abort this entry
console.log(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': User not found '+pm.iterationData.get("file_userid")+', so will now create this user');
// Need to set the ContinuousErrors count to 0 as we got a valid response from the API
// we are authenticated and the user does exist so we can now read the properties that make up this user
);  // the schema read must contain these definitions, otherwise we could be PUTting back missing properties
// reading the current user value of the user properties held in SAP Analytics Cloud.
const SACvalueemail  = readbody.emails[0].value;  // we assume there is only 1 email address in the array and the one we want is the first listed.
// need to grab the user custom parameters next...
// .. then we can get the current value and turn it to a String to allow a comparision with the desired setting
const SACvalueisconcurrent     = customparams.isConcurrent.toString(); // we need to change this boolean value to a string so the compare works
// we can not update the givenname, familyname or displayname
// this script can not update the email address, since the CREATE user request is made before this, and that request would have created a new user if the email
// it means this script can only update the isConcurrent and the managerId
const file_isconcurrent        =pm.iterationData.get("file_isconcurrent").toString(); // the desired value from the file.
// we need to change this boolean value to a string so the compare works
// As we are using custom saml mapping then we need to additionally check if the userName property needs to be updated compared with the file_samlmapping property
// importantly we do NOT check for email, as email is not updatable when SAML SSO is userid
// As we are using custom saml mapping then we need to additionally check if the userName property needs to be updated compared with the file_samlmapping property
// As we are using custom saml mapping then we need to additionally check if the userName property needs to be updated compared with the file_samlmapping property
// importantly we do NOT check for email, as email is not updatable when SAML SSO is custom
// we don't need to check the saml mapping property
// updaterequries will be true or false. It will be true if the values are different, false otherwise
postman.setNextRequest(); // let Postman run the next call to UPDATE user
console.log(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': User already set correctly. Skipping user '+ pm.iterationData.get("file_userid"));
postman.setNextRequest(null); // skip this row in the file and read the next row
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': SCIM schemas have changed. This script is not written for this schmea version and it could corrupt your user. Aborting!');
// we got an unexpected response from the SAC API
if (!errors) { errors=0 };  // in case errors has not yet been set we need to set it to 0
const maxerrors=3;  // maxerrors should be at least 2 to allow for recovery of invalid access token and csrf tokens
// it means a setting of 1 would mean any call following would not be allowed to re-attempt the call.
// a setting of 3 is recommended to allow at least 1 re-attempted call and any subsequent call also failing for a potentially different reason
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Too many continuous errors. Aborting. Response: '+ responseBody);
console.warn(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Continuous errors detected. Response: '+ responseBody);
// we need to read the current properties of the user,
// change the properties we want to and *then* we can PUT back all the user properties correctly having only changed the properties we need to change
const readbody            =pm.variables.get("readbody"); // reading the response body of the previous call that read the user

const preferredlanguage   =readbody.preferredLanguage;  // possible values: 'ar', 'bg', 'zh-CN', 'zh-TW', 'hr', 'ca', 'cs', 'cy', 'nl', 'da', 'en', 'en-GB', 'fi', 'fr', 'fr-CA', 'de', 'de-CH', 'el', 'he', 'hi', 'hu', 'id', 'it', 'ja', 'ko', 'ms', 'no', 'pl', 'pt', 'pt-PT', 'ro', 'ru', 'sh', 'sk', 'sl', 'es', 'es-MX', 'sv', 'th', 'tr', 'uk', 'vi', 'en-US-sappsd' and possibly more will be added over time!
const meta                =readbody.meta;    // changes to the meta isn't allowed
const name                =readbody.name;    // changes to the name isn't allowed
const active              =readbody.active; // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
const roles               =readbody.roles;  // JSON array of SAC roles
const groups              =readbody.groups; // JSON array. Need to use /Groups endpoint until SAC SCIM API support setting groups on a per user basis.

const dataaccesslanguage  =customparams.dataAccessLanguage; // possible values: 'zz' (default), 'af', 'ar', 'bg',  ... many more as shown above in preferredlanguage.
const dateformatting      =customparams.dateFormatting;     // possible values include: 'MMM d, yyyy', 'dd/MM/yyyy', 'MM.dd.yyyy', ... many more!
const timeformatting      =customparams.timeFormatting;     // possible values include: 'H:mm:ss' (24H), 'h:mm:ss A' (12H)
const systemnotificationsemailoptin=customparams.systemNotificationsEmailOptIn; // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
const marketingemailoptin =customparams.marketingEmailOptIn;                    // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
const isconcurrent        =pm.iterationData.get("file_isconcurrent");  // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
// SAP Analytics Cloud is using a custom IdP Mapping on email. When we update the email, we must also update the userName.
// We are using custom SAML SSO mapping so we must read the custom value from the data file
// i.e. SAP Analytics Cloud is using the default IdP or using a custom IdP Mapping on UserID. When this is the case, the userName can NOT be updated.
// if you wish to make simple modifications to this script, do so only by changing the code ***ABOVE*** this line and keep the code ***BELOW*** unchanged.
pm.variables.set("preferredlanguage",preferredlanguage);  // possible values: 'af', 'ar', 'bg',  ... many more as shown above in preferredlanguage.
pm.variables.set("name",JSON.stringify(name));     // JSON array of givenName and familyName
pm.variables.set("active",active);                 // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
pm.variables.set("groups",JSON.stringify(groups)); // JSON array. Need to use /Groups endpoint until SAC SCIM API support setting groups on a per user basis.
//             This entry will be ignored until then but its set here so it will work when supported.
pm.variables.set("dataaccesslanguage",dataaccesslanguage);   // possible values: 'zz' (default), 'af', 'ar', 'bg',  ... many more as shown above in preferredlanguage.
pm.variables.set("dateformatting",dateformatting);  // possible values include: 'MMM d, yyyy', 'dd/MM/yyyy', 'MM.dd.yyyy', ... many more!
pm.variables.set("systemnotificationsemailoptin",systemnotificationsemailoptin); // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
pm.variables.set("marketingemailoptin",marketingemailoptin); // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
pm.variables.set("isconcurrent",isconcurrent);       // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
// we are not authorised, so our accesstoken or the csrf-token must be invalid. We shall get new ones of each!
// A 401 error might be because something is wrong with the call or even the SAP SAC SCIM API, so we need to start counting errors,
// so we don't end up in an endless loop.
console.log(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Fetching a new access token');
// as this is non-GET call, we shall set the 'recovery' to the GET call, so the new session is authorised, once we've obtained a new accesstoken
// We are not authorised, although we have a valid access token and a valid csrf-token!
// We need to issue a GET call to finalise our authorisation.
// It is unlikely we'll get a 403 on this call, but it is possible if the session timed-out between the previous GET and this call, unlikely but possible
// We shall need to get a new access token, new csrf-token and request a GET to finialise the authorisation required on this non-GET calll
// The 'recovery' variable is set to a GET call, when that GET call is issued, the session be fully authorised.
// the user exists because of the previous READ user request. However we can't update the user, most likely due to a conflict of email address, or userName (when SAML SSO is custom)

console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Unable to update user '+ pm.iterationData.get("file_userid") +' with requested SAML mapping '+ pm.iterationData.get("file_samlmapping") +' and with requested email '+ pm.iterationData.get("file_email") +' probably due to email or userName (SAML mapping) conflict with another user. This user could now have a null value for userName! Response: '+ responseBody);

console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Unable to update user '+ pm.iterationData.get("file_userid") +' with requested email '+ pm.iterationData.get("file_email") +' probably due to email conflict with another user. Response: '+ responseBody);
// Need to set the ContinuousErrors count to 0 as we got a valid response from the API
// we updated the user so we can now proceed to the next row in the file.
// we don't need to let Postman run to GET accesstoken
// we got an unexpected response from the SAC API
if (!errors) { errors=0 };  // in case errors has not yet been set we need to set it to 0
const maxerrors=3;  // maxerrors should be at least 2 to allow for recovery of invalid access token and csrf tokens
// it means a setting of 1 would mean any call following would not be allowed to re-attempt the call.
// a setting of 3 is recommended to allow at least 1 re-attempted call and any subsequent call also failing for a potentially different reason
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Too many continuous errors. Aborting. Response: '+ responseBody);
console.warn(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Continuous errors detected. Response: '+ responseBody);
//  Important! Be sure to create users correctly. Its far better to set them correctly at the time of creation rather than having to update users later
//             You can either hard-code the values here (but then you have to repeat these changes everytime you use a new version of this sample script)
//             So, it's better to spend time now to carefully set the values correctly in the Postman Environment.
//             Sample '021 Update New User Default Setting' will set all these Environment values for you.
//             That script will read a user (you provide the userid) and the values for that user are then used as the default values for all new users created.
//             It means you don't need to edit any code :-) If you need different sets of users to be created with different default values, you can either use a different
//             environment for different 'default values' or just re-run sample 021 to update the defaults with differnet values between creating different sets of users.

const preferredlanguage                 =pm.environment.get("SCIM_NewUserDefault_preferredlanguage");  // possible values: 'ar', 'bg', 'zh-CN', 'zh-TW', 'hr', 'ca', 'cs', 'cy', 'nl', 'da', 'en', 'en-GB', 'fi', 'fr', 'fr-CA', 'de', 'de-CH', 'el', 'he', 'hi', 'hu', 'id', 'it', 'ja', 'ko', 'ms', 'no', 'pl', 'pt', 'pt-PT', 'ro', 'ru', 'sh', 'sk', 'sl', 'es', 'es-MX', 'sv', 'th', 'tr', 'uk', 'vi', 'en-US-sappsd' and possibly more will be added over time!
const active                            =pm.environment.get("SCIM_NewUserDefault_active"); // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'

const dataaccesslanguage                =pm.environment.get("SCIM_NewUserDefault_dataaccesslanguage"); // possible values: 'zz' (default), 'af', 'ar', 'bg',  ... many more as shown above in preferredlanguage.
const dateformatting                    =pm.environment.get("SCIM_NewUserDefault_dateformatting");     // possible values include: 'MMM d, yyyy', 'dd/MM/yyyy', 'MM.dd.yyyy', ... many more!
const timeformatting                    =pm.environment.get("SCIM_NewUserDefault_timeformatting");     // possible values include: 'H:mm:ss' (24H), 'h:mm:ss A' (12H)
const systemnotificationsemailoptin     =pm.environment.get("SCIM_NewUserDefault_systemnotificationsemailoptin"); // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
const marketingemailoptin               =pm.environment.get("SCIM_NewUserDefault_marketingemailoptin");                    // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
// In general do not edit below this line unless you want to 'fix' these values and ignore whats in the file.
// You could remove the column/value from the file and fix the value here.
// Any changes you make here are for 'new' users and so you will probably need to update the code in the 'READ user tests' and 'UPDATE user pre-request' for updating existing users
const isconcurrent        =pm.iterationData.get("file_isconcurrent");  // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
// if you wish to make simple modifications to this script, do so only by changing the code ***ABOVE*** this line and keep the code ***BELOW*** unchanged.
// SAP Analytics Cloud is using a custom IdP Mapping on email. The 'email' value here is the userid@domainname. It means the userid created will be derived
// from the userid part which is what we want to achieve with this SAML variant of the sample scripts.
// SAP Analytics Cloud is using a custom IdP Mapping on custom property. It means the userName (SAML Mapping) can be independent for the SAC userid and the email
// here we are setting the username to be the userid as specified in the data file (file_userid). This means the userid email and userName can all be different.
// the username will be updated later in the UPDATE user request later.
// You could decide you do not want to specify the file_userid and instead use just the file_samlmapping. This is ok, but it will only work if the userid is in
// UPPER case and only has the support characters allowed for that userid field (unlike the userName SAML mapping which support more characters and is case sensitive.)
// if you wanted to do this, comment out the line above 'username=userid' and uncomment the next line:
// SAP Analytics Cloud is using a custom IdP Mapping on userid property. This means we must not use the email in the userName as an error will be returned.
// instead we will specify the userid alone
// i.e. SAP Analytics Cloud is using the default IdP, which means the username can be the email or just the userid. If an email address is used, the @domain is dropped
// from ther userName when the user is created.
pm.variables.set("preferredlanguage",preferredlanguage);  // possible values: 'af', 'ar', 'bg',  ... many more as shown above in preferredlanguage.
pm.variables.set("active",active);                 // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
pm.variables.set("email",email);                   // string that is used inside a JSON array of 'value','type','primary'
// pm.variables.set("groups",JSON.stringify(corrected_teams_array)); // JSON array. Need to use /Groups endpoint until SAC SCIM API support setting groups on a per user basis.
//             This entry will be ignored until then but its set here, albeit commented out, so it will work when supported.
//             Once SAP Analytics Cloud supports assigning groups (teams) upon user creation, this line will need to un-commented
//             and an entry into the Body will need to be added:  "groups": {{groups}},
pm.variables.set("dataaccesslanguage",dataaccesslanguage);   // possible values: 'zz' (default), 'af', 'ar', 'bg',  ... many more as shown above in preferredlanguage.
pm.variables.set("dateformatting",dateformatting);  // possible values include: 'MMM d, yyyy', 'dd/MM/yyyy', 'MM.dd.yyyy', ... many more!
pm.variables.set("systemnotificationsemailoptin",systemnotificationsemailoptin); // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
pm.variables.set("marketingemailoptin",marketingemailoptin); // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
pm.variables.set("isconcurrent",isconcurrent);       // possible values: 'true' or 'false' are valid, unlike 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
// we are not authorised, so our accesstoken or the csrf-token must be invalid. We shall get new ones of each!
// A 401 error might be because something is wrong with the call or even the SAP SAC SCIM API, so we need to start counting errors,
// so we don't end up in an endless loop.
if (!errors) { errors=0 };  // in case errors has not yet been set we need to set it to 0
console.log(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Fetching a new access token');
postman.setNextRequest("GET accesstoken"); // once a new accesstoken is successfully returned this call will be repeated thanks to the 'recovery' variable set in the pre-request
// as this is non-GET call, but we don#t need to set NeedGetToBeAuthorised to true as we can just re-read this user to obtain the authorisation needed.
// We shall set the 'recovery' to the GET call, so the new session is authorised, once we've obtained a new accesstoken
// We are not authorised, although we have a valid access token and a valid csrf-token!
// We need to issue a GET call to finalise our authorisation.
// It is unlikely we'll get a 403 on this call, but it is possible if the session timed-out between the previous GET and this call, unlikely but possible
// We shall need to get a new access token, new csrf-token and request a GET to finialise the authorisation required on this non-GET calll
// The 'recovery' variable is set to a GET call, when that GET call is issued, the session be fully authorised.
if (!errors) { errors=0 };  // in case errors has not yet been set we need to set it to 0
// we received a 502 which suggests the user was created but we can't be 100% sure.
// we shall thus go and read the user again, as its likely the user was created.
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Possible error when creating user '+pm.variables.get("userid")+'. Assuming user created ok and re-reading user. Response: '+responseBody);
// there is a conflict and so the user must already exist
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Failed to create user '+pm.variables.get("userid")+'. Possible email conflict with another user. Response: '+responseBody);
// Need to set the ContinuousErrors count to 0 as we got a valid response from the API

console.info(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': User created but with different username than requested. (This sample script will update a users email address) Requested: '+requested_userid+' but created: '+userid_created_in_SAC);
// we got an unexpected response from the SAC API
if (!errors) { errors=0 };  // in case errors has not yet been set we need to set it to 0
const maxerrors=3;  // maxerrors should be at least 2 to allow for recovery of invalid access token and csrf tokens
// it means a setting of 1 would mean any call following would not be allowed to re-attempt the call.
// a setting of 3 is recommended to allow at least 1 re-attempted call and any subsequent call also failing for a potentially different reason
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Too many continuous errors when creating user '+requested_userid+'. Aborting. Response: '+ responseBody);
console.warn(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Continuous errors detected when creating user '+requested_userid+'. Response: '+ responseBody);
console.warn(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Unexpected error when creating user '+requested_userid+'. Response: '+ responseBody);
else  // we are on a Cloud Foundary Platform
pm.environment.set("accesstoken", jsonData.access_token);  // setting the accesstoken so its re-used for all subsequent requests
pm.environment.set("x-csrf-token", "fetch");               // we will need to request a new csrf-token as we have a new session
postman.setNextRequest(pm.variables.get("recovery"));      // we will now return to the request that sent us here in the first place
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Invalid username or password: '+ responseBody);
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Unhandled error. Response Body: '+ responseBody);
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Already attempted to get a valid request. Will now quit');
console.warn(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Will make one more attempt to get a new accesstoken');
const maxerrors=3;  // maxerrors needs to be at least 2, otherwise valid workflows may be able to correctly recover from an invalid access tokens or invalid csrf-tokens
console.error(pm.info.requestName+' '+pm.info.eventName+': Too many continuous errors. Aborting');
